text:
Hi everyone,

I am a freelance content writer and have written a lot of creative blogs and articles for companies. I'm looking to scale up and get better paying clients but it's been difficult. I've used LinkedIn but I've mostly targeted individuals and they're not stable all the time. 

I'm a generalist but I have more experience working as a B2B writer for branding and creative agencies and I also love working as a health and wellness writer because I have a degree in Medicine and Surgery. 

What can I do? I'm hoping to get great clients in April.

elements.text:
Hi everyone,

I am a freelance content writer and have written a lot of creative blogs and articles for companies. I'm looking to scale up and get better paying clients but it's been difficult. I've used LinkedIn but I've mostly targeted individuals and they're not stable all the time. 

I'm a generalist but I have more experience working as a B2B writer for branding and creative agencies and I also love working as a health and wellness writer because I have a degree in Medicine and Surgery. 

What can I do? I'm hoping to get great clients in April.

text:
Hi Favour,

My advice would be to focus on the health and wellness space if that's what you enjoy most. The work will seam easier and until you get your rate to where you want you it to be it, it won't feel as much like undervalued work since it's work you naturally enjoy. You also have subject matter expertise which can be a value add for brands.

If you market yourself as a health and wellness writer, rather than a generalist, (at least) two big things happen:

1. Clients see as you as such, and are more likely to hire a specialist in their niche than a generalist (typically).
2. You can focus your outreach in one area, and develop a network in the space where you might start to get referred (even before writing for them). 
I'd also suggest finding brands you're already aware of that have blogs. These companies already know the value of content and don't need to be educated constantly like an individual / local business would, and are therefore more consistent (and happy to pay for that value).

Clients see as you as such, and are more likely to hire a specialist in their niche than a generalist (typically).

text: Also consider widening the output lens. Beyond blog posts and articles, could you include guides, ebooks, sales collateral, web copy, email/newsletters, etc.?

elements.text: Also consider widening the output lens. Beyond blog posts and articles, could you include guides, ebooks, sales collateral, web copy, email/newsletters, etc.?

text: Hi friends! :woman-raising-hand: Does anyone have any examples of career paths for content marketers? I’m mostly finding paths that lead into people management and broader marketing roles, and I'm curious about what alternative paths might look like for an individual contributor.

elements.text: Hi friends!

Does anyone have any examples of career paths for content marketers? I’m mostly finding paths that lead into people management and broader marketing roles, and I'm curious about what alternative paths might look like for an individual contributor.

attachments.fallback: Your Content Career Headquarters: The 7 Skills That Help Content Marketers Thrive at Work — Your Content Career Headquarters
attachments.text: Content marketing is rich with opportunity, but it's not always easy to identify. There are few clear career trajectories….
attachments.title: The 7 Skills That Help Content Marketers Thrive at Work — Your Content Career Headquarters

text:
Thanks for your insights <@U019MUQNH5H>! I’m at a seed stage startup, so I’ve definitely had to do some messaging work and planning for a new product launch, but haven’t done pricing/packaging optimization. That sounds interesting.

I’ll check out the PMA Core certification and the article you shared :)

Agreed <@U03190ABB53>. I see companies putting Content and Product Marketing in separate buckets, but at startups it seems to be a bit blurry since Content people are better writers as you mentioned. Appreciate the encouragement that knowing both and being able to connect the dots is a huge asset!

I think one thing that makes me weary about startups is just the large amount of change that can happen. I’m adaptable, but sometimes it feels like I’m not growing deeper in my skillset when there are shifting priorities in a biz.

I think one thing that makes me weary about startups is just the large amount of change that can happen. I’m adaptable, but sometimes it feels like I’m not growing deeper in my skillset when there are shifting priorities in a biz.

text:
I figured I would throw this out there and see who has some thoughts.

I have been a one-man show since I started freelancing in Dec 2020. But I have been wanting to scale up to an agency model since summer of 2021.

I feel I have mostly hit a wall in terms of acquiring clients and doing everything else on my own. I am the main breadwinner for my family, so I can't afford to start scaling now without meaning I am taking food out of my family's mouth. But I have noticed a plateau now with what I can get accomplished in the time I have to do everything.

Have any of y'all gotten stuck in this position? How did you overcome? (secondarily, how did you get more clients once you hit that hump to help you get the funding to push through and scale?)

I appreciate the feedback, friends!

elements.text:

I appreciate the feedback, friends!
Thank you!

text:
Hi Shayna, job search is tough no
matter what country or what level of experience you’re at. I run a small British digital marketing recruitment agency & have 20yrs headhunting behind me. Most the work I do is in the UK but some of the same principals apply - I wrote a popular post about how to write a great CV (I know everyone had an opinion but i tried to keep the subjectives views out and concentrate what are hiring managers/recruiters looking for from you - <https://clockworktalent.com/blog-how-to-write-a-great-cv-clockworktalent/|https://clockworktalent.com/blog-how-to-write-a-great-cv-clockworktalent/>

attachments.fallback: clockworkTalent: How To Write A Great CV
attachments.text: If you are about to begin writing a CV or feel yours needs improvements, see this template created by our specialist Digital Recruiters & turn your good CV into a great CV...
attachments.title: How To Write A Great CV

text: Contract out smaller pieces of the work, a little bit at a time. You might have to spread it across multiple contractors but it will allow you to test your SOPs and quality control until you can rev up new business to justify hiring a full time employee

elements.text: Contract out smaller pieces of the work, a little bit at a time. You might have to spread it across multiple contractors but it will allow you to test your SOPs and quality control until you can rev up new business to justify hiring a full time employee

text: Contract out lower value work -- get a VA to help free up more of your time on the admin stuff. I'm not opposed to the agency model, but in my own experience outsourcing writing work doesn't always mean a bigger paycheck for you. It can be hard to find really good writers and still make the profit margins you need -- and if you pay less for a newer writer, you lose even more spending time revising and training them. Getting better quality clients/higher rates can be another way to scale up your income without scaling up stress and additional overhead. Just a thought...all depends on your goals, your strengths, what lights you up, etc. -- if an agency model and managing other people is what you really want to do vs. being a writer than it could be a good fit.

text: A lot of agencies use freelance writers and in fact I think it's easier to get them to respond to a cold pitch than a corporate client. Let them know how your portfolio aligns with the type of work they do or services they offer and ask if they use freelancers and would be interested in speaking further. Keep it short and simple and send out a lot of inquiries.
